awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Olfactory Navigation: Dynamic Computing in the Natural Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This project was developed at an NSF Ideas Lab on "Cracking the Olfactory Code" and is jointly funded by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Physics Division, the Mathematical Biology program in the Division of Mathematical Sciences, the Chemistry of Life Processes program in the Chemistry Division, and the Neural Systems Cluster in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems. The project is a synergistic combination of laboratory experiments and computer modeling that will lead to better understanding of how animals use the sense of smell to navigate in the real world. Almost universally, from flies to mice to dogs, animals use odors to find critical resources, such as food, shelter, and mates. To date, no engineered device can replicate this function and understanding the code used by the brain will lead to many novel applications. Cracking codes, from neural codes to the Enigma code of WWII, is aided by a deep understanding of the content of messages that are being transmitted and how they will be used by their intended receivers. To crack the olfactory code, the team will focus on how odors move in landscapes, how animals extract spatial and temporal cues from odor landscapes, and how they use movement for enhancing these cues while progressing towards their targets. The proposed work encompasses physical measurement of odor plumes, behavioral measurement of animals' paths through olfactory environments, electrophysiological and optical measurement of neural activity during olfactory navigation, perturbations of the environment via virtual reality and of neuronal hardware via genetics, and multilevel mathematical modeling. The PIs will teach and work with undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students and especially recruit students from underrepresented groups in science. The project's results may lead to improved methods for the detection of explosives, new olfactory robots to replace trained animals, and new theoretically-grounded advances in robotic control. The project will inform the development of technologies that interfere with the ability of flying insects (including disease vectors and crop pests) to locate their odor target, thus opening a new door for developing 'green' technologies to solve problems that are of global economic and humanitarian importance.
 
This proposal is a synergistic combination of laboratory experiments and computational modeling that will probe how animals use olfaction to navigate in their environment. Specifically, this effort seeks to solve the difficult problem of olfactory navigation through the following aims: (i) Generate and quantify standardized, naturalistic odor environments that can be used to perform empirical and theoretical tests of navigation strategies; (ii) Determine phenomenological algorithms for odor-guided navigation through behavioral experiments in diverse animal species; (iii) Determine how odor cues for navigation are encoded and used in the nervous system by recording neuronal data and simulating putative neural circuits that implement these processes; (iv) Manipulate olfactory environments and neural circuitry, to evaluate model robustness. In contrast to previous attempts to understand olfactory navigation, the present strategy emphasizes mechanisms that are biologically feasible and explores the wide range of temporal and spatial scales in which animals successfully navigate. The project will generate datasets of immediate use and importance to scientists in theoretical biology and mathematics, engineering (fluid mechanics, electronic olfaction, and robotics) and biology (neuroscience, ecology and evolution).

por.por_cntn:
While the ability of animals to locate odor sources is well known, the neural circuits underlying these behaviors are poorly understood. As an integrated sensori-motor behavior with ancient evolutionary roots, the study of olfactory navigation has the potential to crack open the study of neural circuits and neural codes. The study of bacterial chemotaxis provided pivotal insights into molecular regulatory networks. Similarly, studies of olfactory navigation in diverse organisms promise to reveal basic principles of neural coding, circuit function, and sensori-motor transformation. In this project, we aimed to better understand, at algorithmic and mechanistic levels, how animals use odor to navigate through their environment.  

A central goal was to create and measure the spatial and temporal structure of odor plumes to then guide development of virtual-reality odor environments, and design odor environments for behavioral experiments. The Crimaldi lab developed methodologies and instrumentation for making the first laser-based, high-resolution, non-intrusive measurements of odor plumes in air (Fig. 1).  We then used this instrumentation to acquire time-resolved datasets of odor plume structure for a range of conditions, including flow speed, distance from the bed, and obstacles.  We also developed a system for quantifying odor plumes at large spatial scales in water, and used it to acquire time-resolved datasets of aqueous odor plumes. We then adapted these technologies to develop miniaturized laser-based odor sensors for future incorporation into odor-seeking robots.  

These datasets were then used by the team of collaborators in many ways.  The Victor lab pursued information-theoretic analyses, identifying neural coding strategies that efficiently extracted plume statistics that were informative about source location (Fig. 2), and identified ways in which these strategies could be efficiently implemented in neural circuitry.  The Ermentrout lab used these datasets to characterize the effectiveness of a range of simple navigation algorithms, demonstrating a wide variety of dynamical behaviors and a role for stochastic resonance.

The Nagel lab studied olfactory navigation in fruit flies, a powerful model organism that allows analysis of neural circuits supporting navigation behavior.  They developed a high throughput paradigm to quantify navigational behaviors in response to odor and wind cues. Based on these measurements they constructed models of how flies navigate, which they tested by comparing trajectories of model flies run in simulations based on the Crimaldi lab measurements to the trajectories of real flies navigating in turbulent plumes.  They further identified neural circuits that encode both wind direction and odor identity that may guide flies through their environment.

The Jacobs lab studied olfactory orientation in dogs (Fig. 3) and humans, demonstrating the influence of humidity and temperature on search strategy in trained search dogs trailing humans across a natural landscape. They published a theoretical hypothesis on the evolution and importance of stereo olfaction in human navigation whose predictions were supported by their behavioral studies of humans orienting to odor plumes in real and virtual environments.  

The Verhagen lab asked how biologically plausible simple odor search strategies perform in finding the source of odor plumes and how their performance compares to mice. These minimal strategies, implemented in either robots or computer code, performed remarkably well in low- but not high-turbulence plumes. Mice, however, performed well irrespectively (Fig. 4). They next asked if mice, like insects, can perceive different timings of the whiffs of odor plumes. Indeed, mice can use this information reliably and may use this for navigation in the field. Last, they developed an olfactory virtual reality paradigm to test how odor navigation of mice depends on the moment to moment plume odor sensations. Odor concentration, plume statistics and virtual nose size all affected navigation in mice.

The Urban lab developed novel automated methods to explore mouse behavior during trail following, and their approach led to new insights about navigational behavior. Mice alter their nose position as a function of sniff-by-sniff changes in concentration. Specifically, mice modulate the likelihood of changing the direction of nose movement and the sign of that change, both in a probabilistic fashion. They further optogenetically stimulated olfactory sensory neurons via channel-rhodopsin in freely-moving mice, finding that mice can localize a virtual odor when the proximity to the virtual odor alters either the amplitude or the pulse frequency of the optogenetic stimulation. This approach will allow for highly controlled experiments facilitating understanding of mechanism.

With the Ermentrout lab, the Urban lab  also developed and tested models for spot finding by mice by measuring velocity, rate of turning, and the distribution of nose positions as a function of distance from the odor source. They found that a serial-sniffing strategy (sampling concentration, moving in space, then sampling again) and a stereo-sniffing strategy (inter-nostril comparison of concentration in a single sniff) best explained the behavior.
